title: Java StringhashCode()Method

metadata.description: Learn about Java StringhashCode()Method with clear explanations and practical examples.

content_sections.title: Details
content_sections.content:
Example
Return the hash code of a string:
String myStr = "Hello";
System.out.println(myStr.hashCode());

Definition and Usage
The
hashCode()
method returns the hash code of a string.
The hash code for a String object is computed like this:
s[0]*31^(n-1) + s[1]*31^(n-2) + ... + s[n-1]
where s[i] is the ith character of the string, n is the length of the string, and ^ indicates exponentiation.
Syntax
public int hashCode()
Parameter Values
None.
Technical Details
Returns:
An
int
value, representing the hash code of the string

★
+1

quiz.question: What is The hash code for a String object?
quiz.explanation:
The correct definition of The hash code for a String object is 'computed like this:
s[0]*31^(n-1) + s[1]*31^(n-2) +'.

quiz.question: What is n?
quiz.explanation: The correct definition of n is 'the length of the string'.

summary: This tutorial covers Java StringhashCode()Method concepts and techniques. You'll learn how to use Java StringhashCode()Method effectively, including key principles, common patterns, and practical examples. By the end of this tutorial, you'll have a solid understanding of Java StringhashCode()Method and how to apply it in your projects.
